isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 9200 9300 9400 MODELS BUILT AFTER JANUARY 1, 1995 - ELECTRONIC ENGINE CONTROLS - CATERPILLAR - 1992 - 1993 - ELECTRICAL OPERATION - ELECTRONIC CONTROL MODULE (ECM)

svcprocinfo.para: The "Brain" of the PEEC III and 3176 engine control system is two components working together: the Electronic Control Module (ECM) and the Vehicle Personality Module (VPM). The ECM is mounted on the left side of the engine and the VPM is mounted on the ECM. The ECM is the computer which controls the PEEC III and 3176 engine. The VPM contains operating instructions (software) including owner selected parameters and other engine information for the ECM to use, controlling how the ECM behaves.

The International engine harness connects to the Caterpillar engine harness using International 40-pin OEM connector (191). OEM connector (191) connects to Caterpillar engine harness 40-pin connector J7. All electronic communication between the International electrical system and the Caterpillar engine control system go through (191)/J7, the International/Caterpillar connection.

The ECM receives operating power (12 volt DC) from the vehicle batteries through International engine harness OEM connector (191) when the ignition key switch is in the IGN position. The ECM is intended to operate on 12V, but will tolerate voltage as low as 6 volts during cranking, or 9 volts during normal engine operation. The ECM is protected against power surges on the 12 volt power supply due to alternator load dumps, air conditioner clutches, etc. and for jump starting.
The ECM acts as 5V power supply for many Caterpillar and International components used to monitor and control engine/vehicle systems.

svcsubproc.title: Inputs And Outputs
svcsubproc.para: The ECM is connected to the International installed switches that communicate with the
ECM. The switches are 2-way or 3-way switches and are either ON or OFF.
EXAMPLE OF A 2-WAY SWITCH: Cruise Control ON-OFF Switch (195)

The ECM needs to know if the Cruise ON/OFF switch is in the ON or OFF position. To accomplish this the Cruise ON/OFF switch is connected to the ECM with an input circuit 97AE and a "common" or ground circuit 97-GH.

item.para: Each International installed switch has an "input" circuit that is connected through OEM connector (191) to an assigned ECM terminal. This circuit has 5 volts applied at the ECM terminal.
Each switch is connected to a "common" or ground circuit that is connected through OEM connector (191) terminal #2 to ECM ground (part of Caterpillar harness).

When the Cruise switch is OFF (switch open), the ECM sees 5 volts at ECM terminal 10. Placing the cruise switch to the ON position (switch closed) causes the ECM to see 0 volts (ground voltage will be 0 to 0.5 volts) at terminal 10. The ECM programming has established that the Cruise Control Switch is OFF when it sees 5 volts at OEM connector (191) terminal 10 or cruise is ON when the ECM sees 0 volts at terminal 10.

svcsubproc.para: EXAMPLE: The service brake switch (141) is connected by input circuit 97AL to OEM connector (191) terminal 30. Terminal 30 has a 5-volt signal present. With the brake switch closed (pedal released) the circuit is complete between terminals 30 (input) and 2 (common or ground). This causes the 5 volt signal at terminal 30 to go to zero. This tells the ECM that the service brake switch is closed (pedal released).

This type of circuit is used to communicate switch and some sensor information to the ECM. Some sensors receive a 5 volt signal and return a variable voltage indicating some variable attribute. The ECM also uses 12 volt circuits to enable (activate) relays in the system.
The ECM receives "inputs" through OEM connector (191) from the following International components:

item.para: Vehicle Speed Sensor (VSS) through the Speed Buffer

svcsubproc.para: The ECM also receives and processes information from Caterpillar sensors and switches used to control engine operation including: rack and timing, the fuel shutoff valve, and other engine components. For information on engine operation, refer to the appropriate Caterpillar manual.

svcsubproc.title: KEY ON - Battery Power To ECM
svcsubproc.para: The ECM receives battery power from OEM connector (191) terminal #1 whenever the Ignition Key Switch is in the IGN position.
The battery power to the ECM is switched ON or OFF by the Run Relay (182), which is energized when the key switch is in the IGN position.

item.para: Turning the key switch to the IGN position applies power from fuse F3 on circuit 19A/97A to the Run Relay control coil. This energizes the Run Relay (182), closing the normally open (N.O.) relay contacts (30 - 87). The Run Relay control coil ground path is circuit 11-DB to J7 cab ground.

Run Relay common terminal 30 has battery power present from the ACC Magnetic switch on circuit 97C. With the relay energized, battery power goes through the N.O. terminals (30 to 87) on circuit 97B to 15A fuse H4. From H4, circuit 13D delivers the battery power to OEM connector (191), terminal 1.

svcsubproc.para: It is important to note that 12V battery power from Run Relay is also distributed to: the Throttle Position Sensor (158), the Data Link connector (137), and the Vehicle Speed Buffer (193).

svcsubproc.title: Power To ECM While Cranking Engine (PEEC III ONLY)
svcsubproc.para: Depressing the start button energizes the Start Magnetic Switch sending battery power on circuit 17E to 15A fuse H2. Power from H2 goes on circuit 17F through OEM connector (191) terminal 4 to the ECM.

The ECM uses this power to energize the Fuel Shutoff Solenoid (dual coil solenoid) during the cranking process. When the starter is released, the ECM supplies hold-in voltage keeping the shutoff solenoid energized and no voltage is present from the vehicle on circuit 17F. When the starter button is released, the voltage at OEM connector (191) terminal 4 is turned off.

svcsubproc.title: Manual Fuel Shutoff Lever
svcsubproc.para: There is a manual shutoff lever located on the fuel pump. The shaft has a spring to keep it in the neutral position. The shaft can be manually rotated counter-clockwise to shut fuel OFF or clockwise to manually turn fuel ON.
